sections.text:
### Summary / Problem
We’ve seen regressions where **fit-tier** dominates overall forecasting scores and best-next-action (BNA) rankings, even when **negative deal-dynamics** signals (procurement friction, strong competition, poor internal alignment) should materially reduce confidence and de-prioritize actions. This leads to inflated forecasts and mis-ranked recommendations for “high-fit” accounts that are actually unlikely to close. The GOLD-97 audit identified concrete scenarios and threshold expectations that we should encode to prevent recurrence.

### Proposal
Add a small suite of **automated regression tests** that exercise scoring and ranking behavior under combinations of (a) high-fit tiers and (b) negative deal-dynamics signals. Tests will assert that when any configured risk signals are present, the resulting **forecasting score is capped or penalized** and BNA rankings reflect that downgrade (e.g., risk-mitigation actions outrank expansion/upsell actions). Scenarios, caps/penalties, and pass/fail thresholds will be derived directly from the GOLD-97 audit report and stored as versioned fixtures so changes to scoring logic require explicit updates and review.

### Monitoring / Alerting
Add **lightweight monitoring** to detect real-world drift: a dashboard that tracks score-component distributions (fit-tier contribution vs. deal-dynamics contributions) and highlights workspaces where fit-tier is disproportionately driving the final score **despite the presence of negative deal-dynamics**. We will compute a per-workspace metric such as “% of opportunities with negative dynamics where fit-tier contributes > X% of final score” and alert when it exceeds configured thresholds (again sourced from GOLD-97). Alerts should link to example opportunities and the component breakdown to speed debugging.

### Scope / Implementation Notes
Implementation will include: (1) a deterministic test harness that can score synthetic opportunities with explicit signal toggles and validate both absolute score bounds and relative BNA ordering; (2) configuration for thresholds/caps stored in code (or a single config file) with clear provenance to GOLD-97; (3) an internal dashboard (e.g., existing metrics stack) and an alert rule per workspace and globally. Out of scope: changing the underlying scoring model beyond enforcing the tested caps/penalties; any model changes prompted by failures will follow-up separately, with the regression suite serving as the guardrail.
